										      >	| ::: {#Enterprise_Applications}    | Applications that are provided    |
										      >	| Enterprise Applications           | and managed by the enterprise as  |
										      >	| :::                               | opposed to a public application   |
										      >	|                                   | store.                            |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Enterprise_Data}            | Any data residing in enterprise   |
										      >	| Enterprise Data                   | servers or temporarily stored on  |
										      >	| :::                               | mobile devices to which the       |
										      >	|                                   | mobile device user is allowed     |
										      >	|                                   | access according to the security  |
										      >	|                                   | policy defined by the enterprise  |
										      >	|                                   | and implemented by the            |
										      >	|                                   | administrator.                    |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Key_Encryption_Key}         | A key that is used to encrypt     |
										      >	| Key Encryption Key                | other keys, such as (DEKs) or     |
										      >	| ([KEK](#abbr_KEK))                | storage repositories that contain |
										      >	| :::                               | keys.                             |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Locked_State}               | Mobile device state where the     |
										      >	| Locked State                      | device is powered on but most     |
										      >	| :::                               | functionality is unavailable for  |
										      >	|                                   | use without authentication.       |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Mobile_Device}              | A device which is composed of a   |
										      >	| Mobile Device ([MD](#abbr_MD))    | hardware platform and its system  |
										      >	| :::                               | software. The device typically    |
										      >	|                                   | provides wireless connectivity    |
										      >	|                                   | and may include software for      |
										      >	|                                   | functions like secure messaging,  |
										      >	|                                   | email, web, VPN connection, and   |
										      >	|                                   | VoIP (Voice over IP), for access  |
										      >	|                                   | to the protected enterprise       |
										      >	|                                   | network, enterprise data and      |
										      >	|                                   | applications, and for             |
										      >	|                                   | communicating to other MDs.       |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Mobile_Device_Management}   | Products that allow enterprises   |
										      >	| Mobile Device Management          | to apply security policies to     |
										      >	| ([MDM](#abbr_MDM))                | MDs. This system consists of two  |
										      >	| :::                               | primary components: the           |
										      >	|                                   | [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server and the   |
										      >	|                                   | [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent.           |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Mobile_Device_User}         | The person who uses and is held   |
										      >	| Mobile Device User                | responsible for an                |
										      >	| :::                               | [MD](#abbr_MD).                   |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Operating_System}           | Software which runs at the        |
										      >	| Operating System ([OS](#abbr_OS)) | highest privilege level and can   |
										      >	| :::                               | directly control hardware         |
										      >	|                                   | resources. Modern mobile devices  |
										      >	|                                   | typically have at least two       |
										      >	|                                   | primary operating systems: one    |
										      >	|                                   | which runs on the cellular        |
										      >	|                                   | baseband processor and one which  |
										      >	|                                   | runs on the application           |
										      >	|                                   | processor. The platform of the    |
										      >	|                                   | application processor handles     |
										      >	|                                   | most user interaction and         |
										      >	|                                   | provides the execution            |
										      >	|                                   | environment for apps. The         |
										      >	|                                   | platform of the cellular baseband |
										      >	|                                   | processor handles communications  |
										      >	|                                   | with the cellular network and may |
										      >	|                                   | control other peripherals. The    |
										      >	|                                   | term [OS](#abbr_OS), without      |
										      >	|                                   | context, may be assumed to refer  |
										      >	|                                   | to the platform of the            |
										      >	|                                   | application processor.            |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Powered-Off_State}          | Mobile device shutdown state.     |
										      >	| Powered-Off State                 |                                   |
										      >	| :::                               |                                   |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Protected_Data}             | All non-TSF data on the mobile    |
										      >	| Protected Data                    | device, including user or         |
										      >	| :::                               | enterprise data. Protected data   |
										      >	|                                   | is encrypted while the mobile     |
										      >	|                                   | device is in the powered-off      |
										      >	|                                   | state. This includes keys in      |
										      >	|                                   | software-based storage. May       |
										      >	|                                   | overlap with sensitive data.      |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Root_Encryption_Key}        | A key tied to a particular device |
										      >	| Root Encryption Key               | that is used to encrypt all other |
										      >	| ([REK](#abbr_REK))                | keys for that device.             |
										      >	| :::                               |                                   |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Sensitive_Data}             | Data that is encrypted by the     |
										      >	| Sensitive Data                    | mobile device. May include all    |
										      >	| :::                               | user or enterprise data or may be |
										      >	|                                   | data for specific applications    |
										      >	|                                   | such as emails, messaging,        |
										      >	|                                   | documents, calendar items, or     |
										      >	|                                   | contacts. May be protected while  |
										      >	|                                   | the mobile device is in the       |
										      >	|                                   | locked state. Must include at     |
										      >	|                                   | minimum some keys in              |
										      >	|                                   | software-based key storage.       |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Trust_Anchor_Database}      | A list of trusted root            |
										      >	| Trust Anchor Database             | Certificate Authority             |
										      >	| :::                               | certificates.                     |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Unenrolled_State}           | Mobile device state when it is    |
										      >	| Unenrolled State                  | not managed by an                 |
										      >	| :::                               | [MDM](#abbr_MDM).                 |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+
										      >	| ::: {#Unlocked_State}             | Mobile device state where it is   |
										      >	| Unlocked State                    | powered on and its functionality  |
										      >	| :::                               | is available for use.             |
										      >	+-----------------------------------+-----------------------------------+

configuration\" and identify components that may have instances added to	      |	[TOE](#abbr_TOE). (Note that this deliverable is examined as part of the

[CC](#abbr_CC){.abbr} certification[.](#ajq_124){#ajq_124} Appendix E		      |	Activities.) The [ST](#abbr_ST) for a distributed [TOE](#abbr_TOE) may

										      >	may have instances added to an operational configuration without
										      >	affecting the validity of the [CC](#abbr_CC) certification. Appendix E
describes Evaluation Activities relating to these equivalency aspects of		describes Evaluation Activities relating to these equivalency aspects of
a distributed [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} (and hence what is expected in the	      |	a distributed [TOE](#abbr_TOE) (and hence what is expected in the
[ST](#abbr_ST){.abbr})[.](#ajq_125){#ajq_125}					      |	[ST](#abbr_ST)).
										      >
										      >	3.3 Security Audit for Distributed TOEs {#dis .indexable data-level="2"}
										      >	---------------------------------------
										      >
										      >	\
										      >	For distributed TOEs the handling of audit information might be more
										      >	complicated than for TOEs consisting only of one component. There are a
										      >	few basic requirements to be fulfilled:\
										      >	\
										      >
										      >	-   Every component must be able to generate audit information.
										      >	-   Every component must be able to buffer audit information and forward
										      >	    it to another [TOE](#abbr_TOE) component or an external audit
										      >	    server. Optionally, each componemt may store audit information
										      >	    locally.
										      >	-   For the overall [TOE](#abbr_TOE) it must be possible to send out
										      >	    audit information to an external audit server.
										      >
										      >	\
										      >	In general, every component must be able to generate its own audit
										      >	information. It would be possible that every component also stores its
										      >	own audit information locally as well as every component could be able
										      >	to send out audit data to an external audit server. It would also be
										      >	sufficient that every component would be able to generate its own audit
										      >	data and buffer it locally before the information is sent out to one or
										      >	more other [TOE](#abbr_TOE) components for local storage and/or
										      >	transmission to an external audit server. For the transfer of audit
										      >	records between [TOE](#abbr_TOE) components the secure connection via
										      >	FTP\_ITC.1 or [FPT\_ITT.1/INTER\_XFER](#FPT_ITT.1/INTER_XFER) /
										      >	[FPT\_ITT.1/INTER\_XFER\_AGENT](#FPT_ITT.1/INTER_XFER_AGENT) must be
										      >	used.\
										      >	\
										      >	Such a solution would still be suitable to fulfil the requirement that
										      >	all audit-related SFRs have to be fulfilled by all [TOE](#abbr_TOE)
										      >	components, although formally not every component would support local
										      >	storage or transfer to an external audit server itself.\
										      >	\
										      >	Regarding the establishment of inter-TOE communication, error conditions
										      >	as well as successful connection/teardown events should be captured by
										      >	both ends of the connection.\
										      >	\
										      >	All [TOE](#abbr_TOE) components shall be able to generate its own audit
										      >	data according to FAU\_GEN.1 for all SFRs that it implements. For
										      >	distributed TOEs, a mapping shall be provided to show which auditable
										      >	events according to FAU\_GEN.1 are covered by which components (also
										      >	giving a justification that the records generated by each component
										      >	cover all the SFRs that it implements). The overall [TOE](#abbr_TOE) has
										      >	to provide audit information about all events defined for FAU\_GEN.1. As
										      >	a result, at least one [TOE](#abbr_TOE) component has to be assigned to
										      >	every auditable event defined for FAU\_GEN.1. The part of the mapping
										      >	related to [Table
										      >	[3]{.counter}](#t-audit-mandatory){.t-audit-mandatory-ref} shall be
										      >	consistent with the mapping of SFRs to [TOE](#abbr_TOE) components for
										      >	[ASE\_TSS.1](#ASE_TSS.1) in the sense that all components defined as
										      >	generating audit information for a particular [SFR](#abbr_SFR) should
										      >	also contribute to that [SFR](#abbr_SFR) in the mapping for
										      >	[ASE\_TSS.1](#ASE_TSS.1). This applies not only to audit events defined
										      >	for mandatory SFRs but also to all audit events for optional,
										      >	selection-based, and objective SFRs as defined in [Section
										      >	[optional-reqs]{.counter}](#optional-reqs){.optional-reqs-ref}, [Section
										      >	[sel-based-reqs]{.counter}](#sel-based-reqs){.sel-based-reqs-ref}, and
										      >	[Section
										      >	[objective-reqs]{.counter}](#objective-reqs){.objective-reqs-ref}.\
										      >	\
										      >	If one or more of the optional audit components
										      >	[FAU\_STG\_EXT.1](#FAU_STG_EXT.1) or [FAU\_STG\_EXT.2](#FAU_STG_EXT.2)
										      >	are selected in the [ST](#abbr_ST) derived from this [PP](#abbr_PP),
										      >	then the [SFR](#abbr_SFR) mapping for [ASE\_TSS.1](#ASE_TSS.1) must
										      >	include a specific identification of the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) components to
										      >	which they apply.

::: {#FAU_DIS_EXT.1 .comp}							      <
#### FAU\_DIS\_EXT.1 Security Audit for Distributed TOEs			      <
										      <
::: {.element}									      <
::: {#FAU_DIS_EXT.1.1 .reqid}							      <
[FAU\_DIS\_EXT.1.1](#FAU_DIS_EXT.1.1){.abbr}					      <
:::										      <
										      <
::: {.reqdesc}									      <
For distributed [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr}\'s the handling of audit		      <
information might be more complicated than for					      <
[TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr}\'s consisting only of one				      <
component[.](#ajq_388){#ajq_388} There are a few basic requirements to		      <
be fulfilled:\									      <
\										      <
										      <
-   Every component must be able to generate audit				      <
    information[.](#ajq_389){#ajq_389}						      <
-   Every component must be able to buffer audit information and forward	      <
    it to another [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} component and optionally store	      <
    audit information locally[.](#ajq_390){#ajq_390}				      <
-   For the overall [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} it must be possible to send		      <
    out audit information to an external audit					      <
    server[.](#ajq_391){#ajq_391}						      <
										      <
\										      <
In general, every component must be able to generate its own audit		      <
information[.](#ajq_392){#ajq_392} It would be possible that every		      <
component also stores its own audit information locally as well as every	      <
component could be able to send out audit data to an external audit		      <
server[.](#ajq_393){#ajq_393} It would also be sufficient that every		      <
component would be able to generate its own audit data and buffer it		      <
locally before the information is sent out to one or more other			      <
[TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} components for local storage and/or transmission	      <
to an external audit server[.](#ajq_394){#ajq_394} For the transfer of		      <
audit records between [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} components the secure		      <
connection via FTP\_ITC.1 or [FPT\_ITT.1](#FPT_ITT.1){.linkref} must be		      <
used[.](#ajq_395){#ajq_395}\							      <
\										      <
Such a solution would still be suitable to fulfil the requirement that		      <
all audit-related [SFR](#abbr_SFR){.abbr}\'s have to be fulfilled by all	      <
[TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} components, although formally not every			      <
component would support local storage or transfer to an external audit		      <
server itself[.](#ajq_396){#ajq_396}\						      <
\										      <
Regarding the establishment of inter-[TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr}			      <
communication, error conditions as well as successful				      <
connection/teardown events should be captured by both ends of the		      <
connection[.](#ajq_397){#ajq_397}\						      <
\										      <
Although all [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} components shall be able to		      <
generate their own audit data according to FAU\_GEN.1 for all the		      <
[SFR](#abbr_SFR){.abbr}\'s that they implement, not all				      <
[TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} components have to provide audit data about all		      <
events[.](#ajq_398){#ajq_398} For distributed [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr}\'s	      <
a mapping shall be provided to show which auditable events according to		      <
FAU\_GEN.1 are covered by which components (also giving a justification		      <
that the records generated by each component cover all the			      <
[SFR](#abbr_SFR){.abbr}\'s that it implements)[.](#ajq_399){#ajq_399}		      <
The overall [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} has to provide audit information		      <
about all events defined for FAU\_GEN.1[.](#ajq_400){#ajq_400} As a		      <
result, at least one [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} component has to be		      <
assigned to every auditable event defined for					      <
FAU\_GEN.1[.](#ajq_401){#ajq_401} The part of the mapping related to		      <
Table 2 shall be consistent with the mapping of					      <
[SFR](#abbr_SFR){.abbr}\'s to [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} components for		      <
ASE\_TSS.1 in the sense that all components defined as generating audit		      <
information for a particular SFR should also contribute to that SFR in		      <
the mapping for ASE\_TSS.1[.](#ajq_402){#ajq_402} This applies not only		      <
to audit events defined for mandatory [SFR](#abbr_SFR){.abbr}\'s but		      <

[SFR](#abbr_SFR){.abbr}\'s as defined in Appendix A, B, and			      <
C[.](#ajq_403){#ajq_403}\							      <
\										      <
If one or more of the optional audit components					      <
[FAU\_STG\_EXT.1](#FAU_STG_EXT.1){.linkref} or					      <

										      >	Tests
:::											:::
										      >
										      >	#### If \"implement functionality\" is selected:
										      >
										      >	The evaluator shall perform the following tests.\
										      >	\
										      >	The evaluator shall perform 15 trials for the RNG implementation. If the
										      >	RNG is configurable, the evaluator shall perform 15 trials for each
										      >	configuration. The evaluator shall also confirm that the operational
										      >	guidance contains appropriate instructions for configuring the RNG
										      >	functionality.\
										      >	\
										      >	If the RNG has prediction resistance enabled, each trial consists of (1)
										      >	instantiate DRBG, (2) generate the first block of random bits, (3)
										      >	generate a second block of random bits, and (4) uninstantiate. The
										      >	evaluator verifies that the second block of random bits is the expected
										      >	value. The evaluator shall generate eight input values for each trial.
										      >	The first is a count (0 - 14). The next three are entropy input, nonce,
										      >	and personalization string for the instantiate operation. The next two
										      >	are additional input and entropy input for the first call to generate.
										      >	The final two are additional input and entropy input for the second call
										      >	to generate. These values are randomly generated. \"generate one block
										      >	of random bits\" means to generate random bits with number of returned
										      >	bits equal to the Output Block Length (as defined in NIST SP 800-90A).\
										      >	\
										      >	If the RNG does not have prediction resistance, each trial consists of
										      >	(1) instantiate DRBG, (2) generate the first block of random bits (3)
										      >	reseed, (4) generate a second block of random bits, and (5)
										      >	uninstantiate. The evaluator verifies that the second block of random
										      >	bits is the expected value. The evaluator shall generate eight input
										      >	values for each trial. The first is a count (0 - 14). The next three are
										      >	entropy input, nonce, and personalization string for the instantiate
										      >	operation. The fifth value is additional input to the first call to
										      >	generate. The sixth and seventh are additional input and entropy input
										      >	to the call to reseed. The final value is additional input to the second
										      >	generate call.\
										      >	\
										      >	The following paragraphs contain more information on some of the input
										      >	values to be generated/selected by the evaluator.\
										      >	\
										      >	Entropy input: the length of the entropy input value must equal the seed
										      >	length.\
										      >	\
										      >	Nonce: If a nonce is supported (CTR\_DRBG with no Derivation Function
										      >	does not use a nonce), the nonce bit length is one-half the seed
										      >	length.\
										      >	\
										      >	Personalization string: The length of the personalization string must be
										      >	less than or equal to seed length. If the implementation only supports
										      >	one personalization string length, then the same length can be used for
										      >	both values. If more than one string length is support, the evaluator
										      >	shall use personalization strings of two different lengths. If the
										      >	implementation does not use a personalization string, no value needs to
										      >	be supplied.\
										      >	\
										      >	Additional input: the additional input bit lengths have the same
										      >	defaults and restrictions as the personalization string lengths.\
										      >	\

										      >	data that may be used in support of securing data in transit.
										      >
										      >	[FCS\_STG\_EXT.2](#FCS_STG_EXT.2) (sel-based)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FCS\_STG\_EXT.2](#FCS_STG_EXT.2) to define
										      >	the method the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) uses to protect stored key data that may
										      >	be used in support of securing data in transit.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_ENR\_EXT.1](#FIA_ENR_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_ENR\_EXT.1](#FIA_ENR_EXT.1) which
										      >	requires the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to use a trusted channel for the agent
										      >	enrollment process.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.1/CERTVAL\_MAN](#FIA_X509_EXT.1/CERTVAL_MAN)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.1/CERTVAL\_MAN](#FIA_X509_EXT.1/CERTVAL_MAN) to define
										      >	validation rules for X.509 certificates that may be used in support of
										      >	securing data in transit.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.1/CERTVAL\_SEL](#FIA_X509_EXT.1/CERTVAL_SEL) (sel-based)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.1/CERTVAL\_SEL](#FIA_X509_EXT.1/CERTVAL_SEL) to define
										      >	validation rules for X.509 certificates that may be used in support of
										      >	securing data in transit in the specific case where the [TOE](#abbr_TOE)
										      >	is distributed across multiple remote nodes.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.2](#FIA_X509_EXT.2)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_X509\_EXT.2](#FIA_X509_EXT.2) to
										      >	define the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) functions that support the use of X.509
										      >	certificates. This includes protection of data in transit.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.3](#FIA_X509_EXT.3) (objective)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_X509\_EXT.3](#FIA_X509_EXT.3) to
										      >	define X.509 enrollment activities using PKCS\#10 to allow the
										      >	[TOE](#abbr_TOE) to obtain a signed certificate for use when
										      >	establishing trusted communications.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.4](#FIA_X509_EXT.4) (objective)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_X509\_EXT.3](#FIA_X509_EXT.3) to
										      >	define X.509 enrollment activities using [EST](#abbr_EST) to allow the
										      >	[TOE](#abbr_TOE) to obtain a signed certificate for use when
										      >	establishing trusted communications.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.5](#FIA_X509_EXT.5)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_X509\_EXT.5](#FIA_X509_EXT.5) to
										      >	require the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to enforce uniqueness for client
										      >	certificates that are used in support of securing data in transit.
										      >
										      >	[FPT\_ITT.1/INTER\_XFER](#FPT_ITT.1/INTER_XFER) (sel-based)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FPT\_ITT.1/INTER\_XFER](#FPT_ITT.1/INTER_XFER) to define how data is
										      >	secured in transit between [TOE](#abbr_TOE) components if the
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) server itself is distributed.
										      >
										      >	[FPT\_ITT.1/INTER\_XFER\_AGENT](#FPT_ITT.1/INTER_XFER_AGENT) (sel-based)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FPT\_ITT.1/INTER\_XFER\_AGENT](#FPT_ITT.1/INTER_XFER_AGENT) to define
										      >	how data is secured in transit between the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) server and
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) agent if both are part of the [TOE](#abbr_TOE).
										      >
										      >	[FTP\_ITC\_EXT.1](#FTP_ITC_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FTP\_ITC\_EXT.1](#FTP_ITC_EXT.1) to define
										      >	the trusted channels used by the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) where security of data
										      >	in transit is enforced.
										      >
										      >	[FTP\_ITC.1/INTER\_XFER\_IT](#FTP_ITC.1/INTER_XFER_IT)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FTP\_ITC.1/INTER\_XFER\_IT](#FTP_ITC.1/INTER_XFER_IT) to define a
										      >	trusted communication channel between itself and trusted external
										      >	servers.
										      >
										      >	[FTP\_ITC.1/INTER\_TSF\_XFER\_AGENT](#FTP_ITC.1/INTER_TSF_XFER_AGENT)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FTP\_ITC.1/INTER\_TSF\_XFER\_AGENT](#FTP_ITC.1/INTER_TSF_XFER_AGENT) to
										      >	define a trusted communication channel between itself and an
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) agent if the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) agent is not part of the
										      >	[TOE](#abbr_TOE).
										      >
										      >	[FTP\_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH\_REM\_ADMIN](#FTP_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH_REM_ADMIN)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FTP\_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH\_REM\_ADMIN](#FTP_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH_REM_ADMIN) to
										      >	define requirements for securing data in transit for administrative
										      >	communications.
										      >
										      >	[FTP\_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH\_ENROLL](#FTP_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH_ENROLL)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FTP\_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH\_ENROLL](#FTP_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH_ENROLL) to define
										      >	requirements for securing data in transit for agent enrollment.
										      >
										      >	[FTP\_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH\_JOIN](#FTP_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH_JOIN)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FTP\_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH\_JOIN](#FTP_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH_JOIN) to define
										      >	requirements for securing data in transit between [TOE](#abbr_TOE)
										      >	components when establishing initial connectivity if the
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) server itself is distributed and a separate
										      >	registration channel is used.
										      >
										      >	[O.INTEGRITY](#O.INTEGRITY)\
										      >
										      >	[FCS\_COP.1/HASH\_ALG](#FCS_COP.1/HASH_ALG)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FCS\_COP.1/HASH\_ALG](#FCS_COP.1/HASH_ALG)
										      >	to require the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to include a mechanism to
										      >	cryptographically assert and verity the integrity of data using a hash
										      >	algorithm.
										      >
										      >	FCS\_COP.1/SIG\_ALG
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes FCS\_COP.1(3) to require the
										      >	[TSF](#abbr_TSF) to include a mechanism to cryptographically assert and
										      >	verify the integrity of data using a digital signature.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.2](#FIA_X509_EXT.2)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_X509\_EXT.2](#FIA_X509_EXT.2) to
										      >	define the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) functions that support the use of X.509
										      >	certificates. This includes code signing for system software updates,
										      >	integrity verification, and policy signing.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_POL\_EXT.1](#FMT_POL_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FMT\_POL\_EXT.1](#FMT_POL_EXT.1) to ensure
										      >	the integrity of the policies and policy updates to the [MDM](#abbr_MDM)
										      >	Agent are digitally signed to protect their integrity.
										      >
										      >	[FCO\_CPC\_EXT.1](#FCO_CPC_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FCO\_CPC\_EXT.1](#FCO_CPC_EXT.1) to define
										      >	secure connectivity between different [TOE](#abbr_TOE) components,
										      >	including security of data in transit.
										      >
										      >	[FPT\_TST\_EXT.1](#FPT_TST_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FPT\_TST\_EXT.1](#FPT_TST_EXT.1) to require
										      >	The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to run a suite of self tests to ensure the correct
										      >	operation of the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) and the integrity of stored
										      >	[TSF](#abbr_TSF) executable code.
										      >
										      >	[FPT\_TUD\_EXT.1](#FPT_TUD_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FPT\_TUD\_EXT.1](#FPT_TUD_EXT.1) to define
										      >	requirements for trusted update of [TSF](#abbr_TSF) executable code,
										      >	including that the integrity of this update data can be verified.
										      >
										      >	[O.MANAGEMENT](#O.MANAGEMENT)\
										      >
										      >	[FAU\_CRP\_EXT.1](#FAU_CRP_EXT.1) (objective)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FAU\_CRP\_EXT.1](#FAU_CRP_EXT.1) to require
										      >	certain data to be collected from remote agents using a secure channel.
										      >
										      >	[FAU\_SAR.1](#FAU_SAR.1) (optional)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FAU\_SAR.1](#FAU_SAR.1) to optionally
										      >	require the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to implement management functionality to
										      >	review audit data that is restricted to authorized users.
										      >
										      >	[FAU\_SEL.1](#FAU_SEL.1) (optional)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FAU\_SEL.1](#FAU_SEL.1) to optionally
										      >	require the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to implement management functionality for
										      >	configuring the events that are audited.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_ENR\_EXT.1](#FIA_ENR_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_ENR\_EXT.1](#FIA_ENR_EXT.1) which
										      >	requires the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to use a trusted channel for the agent
										      >	enrollment process.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_UAU.1](#FIA_UAU.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FIA\_UAU.1](#FIA_UAU.1) to require the
										      >	[TSF](#abbr_TSF) to enforce access control on its management interface
										      >	by requiring user authentication.
										      >
										      >	[FIA\_UAU\_EXT.4/REUSE](#FIA_UAU_EXT.4/REUSE) (objective)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FIA\_UAU\_EXT.4/REUSE](#FIA_UAU_EXT.4/REUSE) to optionally require the
										      >	[TSF](#abbr_TSF) to limit enrollment through the prevention of reuse of
										      >	enrollment authentication data.
										      >
										      >	FIA\_UAU\_EXT.4/2 (objective)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes FIA\_UAU\_EXT.4(2) to provide access
										      >	controls to prevent the reuse of enrollment data related to device
										      >	enrollment. The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) shall prevent two devices to be
										      >	enrolled using the same unique identifier.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_MOF.1/FUNCBE](#FMT_MOF.1/FUNCBE)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FMT\_MOF.1/FUNCBE](#FMT_MOF.1/FUNCBE) for
										      >	the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) to restrict the functions to enable, disable,
										      >	modify, and monitor functions and policies to authorized administrators.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT\_ENROLL](#FMT_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT_ENROLL)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FMT\_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT\_ENROLL](#FMT_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT_ENROLL) to
										      >	restrict the enrollment process to authorized administrators and mobile
										      >	device users.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT\_MAS](#FMT_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT_MAS)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FMT\_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT\_MAS](#FMT_MOF.1/MANAGEMENT_MAS) to enforce
										      >	restrictions on access to the MAS Server from enrolled devices based on
										      >	applied policies.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_POL\_EXT.1](#FMT_POL_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FMT\_POL\_EXT.1](#FMT_POL_EXT.1) to ensure
										      >	the integrity of the policies and policy updates to the [MDM](#abbr_MDM)
										      >	Agent are digitally signed to protect their integrity.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_SMF.1/SERVER\_CONF\_AGENT](#FMT_SMF.1/SERVER_CONF_AGENT)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FMT\_SMF.1/SERVER\_CONF\_AGENT](#FMT_SMF.1/SERVER_CONF_AGENT) to define
										      >	the security-relevant management functions that the [MDM](#abbr_MDM)
										      >	server is capable of communicating to the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_SMF.1/SERVER\_CONF\_SERVER](#FMT_SMF.1/SERVER_CONF_SERVER)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FMT\_SMF.1/SERVER\_CONF\_SERVER](#FMT_SMF.1/SERVER_CONF_SERVER) to
										      >	define the security-relevant management functions that the
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) server has for its own configuration.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_SMF.1/MAS](#FMT_SMF.1/MAS)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FMT\_SMF.1/MAS](#FMT_SMF.1/MAS) to define
										      >	the MAS Server management functionality if this capability is supported.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_SMR.1/SECMAN\_ROLES](#FMT_SMR.1/SECMAN_ROLES)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FMT\_SMR.1/SECMAN\_ROLES](#FMT_SMR.1/SECMAN_ROLES) to define the
										      >	security management roles that are used as the basis for access control
										      >	enforcement.
										      >
										      >	[FMT\_SMR.1/SECMAN\_ROLES\_MAS](#FMT_SMR.1/SECMAN_ROLES_MAS) (sel-based)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes
										      >	[FMT\_SMR.1/SECMAN\_ROLES\_MAS](#FMT_SMR.1/SECMAN_ROLES_MAS) to define
										      >	the management roles that apply to the MAS Server if this capability is
										      >	supported.
										      >
										      >	[FTA\_TAB.1](#FTA_TAB.1) (optional)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FTA\_TAB.1](#FTA_TAB.1) to display an
										      >	Administrator-specified advisory notice and consent warning message
										      >	regarding use of the [TOE](#abbr_TOE).
										      >
										      >	[O.QUALITY](#O.QUALITY)\
										      >
										      >	[FPT\_API\_EXT.1](#FPT_API_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FPT\_API\_EXT.1](#FPT_API_EXT.1) to enforce
										      >	quality of implementation by ensuring that the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) software
										      >	uses only documented platform APIs to supports its security
										      >	functionality.
										      >
										      >	[FPT\_LIB\_EXT.1](#FPT_LIB_EXT.1)
										      >
										      >	The [PP](#abbr_PP) includes [FPT\_LIB\_EXT.1](#FPT_LIB_EXT.1) to enforce
										      >	quality of implementation by ensuring that the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) software
										      >	does not include any unnecessary or unexpected third-party libraries
										      >	which could present a privacy threat or vulnerability.
										      >
										      >	6.2 Security Assurance Requirements {#SARs .indexable data-level="2"}
										      >	-----------------------------------
										      >
										      >	The Security Objectives for the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) in [Section 6 Security
										      >	Requirements](#req){.dynref} were constructed to address threats
										      >	identified in [Section 4.1 Threats](#threats){.dynref}. The Security
										      >	Functional Requirements (SFRs) in [Section 6 Security
										      >	Requirements](#req){.dynref} are a formal instantiation of the Security
										      >	Objectives. The [PP](#abbr_PP) identifies the Security Assurance
										      >	Requirements (SARs) to frame the extent to which the evaluator assesses
										      >	the documentation applicable for the evaluation and performs independent
										      >	testing.\
										      >	This section lists the set of SARs from [CC](#abbr_CC) part 3 that are
										      >	required in evaluations against this [PP](#abbr_PP). Individual
										      >	Evaluation Activities (AAs) to be performed are specified both in
										      >	[Section 6 Security Requirements](#req){.dynref} as well as in this
										      >	section.\
										      >	\
										      >	The general model for evaluation of TOEs against STs written to conform
										      >	to this [PP](#abbr_PP) is as follows:\
										      >	\
										      >	After the [ST](#abbr_ST) has been approved for evaluation, the ITSEF
										      >	will obtain the [TOE](#abbr_TOE), supporting environmental IT, and the
										      >	administrative/user guides for the [TOE](#abbr_TOE). The ITSEF is
										      >	expected to perform actions mandated by the Common Evaluation
										      >	Methodology ([CEM](#abbr_CEM)) for the ASE and ALC SARs. The ITSEF also
										      >	performs the Evaluation Activities contained within [Section 6 Security
										      >	Requirements](#req){.dynref}, which are intended to be an interpretation
										      >	of the other [CEM](#abbr_CEM) assurance requirements as they apply to
										      >	the specific technology instantiated in the [TOE](#abbr_TOE). The
										      >	Evaluation Activities that are captured in [Section 6 Security
Requirements](#req){.dynref} also provide clarification as to what the			Requirements](#req){.dynref} also provide clarification as to what the
developer needs to provide to demonstrate the [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} is	      |	developer needs to provide to demonstrate the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) is
compliant with the [PP](#abbr_PP){.abbr}[.](#ajq_1114){#ajq_1114}\		      |	compliant with the [PP](#abbr_PP).\
\											\
The [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} security assurance requirements are			      |	The [TOE](#abbr_TOE) security assurance requirements are identified in

### 7.2.1 Basic Functional Specification (ADV\_FSP.1) {#fsp .indexable data-level="3" |	The design information about the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) is contained in the
										      >	guidance documentation available to the end user as well as the
										      >	[TSS](#abbr_TSS) portion of the [ST](#abbr_ST), and any additional

[Application Note: ]{.note-header}[						      <
[FIA\_X509\_EXT.1.1(2)](#FIA_X509_EXT.1.1(2)){.linkref} should be chosen	      <
if the [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} is distributed and the protocol(s)		      <
selected in [FPT\_ITT.1](#FPT_ITT.1){.linkref} utilize X.509			      <
certificates for peer authentication[.](#ajq_1363){#ajq_1363} In this		      <
case, the use of revocation list checking is optional as there are		      <
additional requirements surrounding the enabling and disabling of the		      <
ITT channel as defined in							      <
[FCO\_CPC\_EXT.1](#FCO_CPC_EXT.1){.linkref}[.](#ajq_1364){#ajq_1364} If		      <
revocation checking is not supported, the [ST](#abbr_ST){.abbr} author		      <
should select no revocation method[.](#ajq_1365){#ajq_1365} However, if		      <
certificate revocation checking is supported, the [ST](#abbr_ST){.abbr}		      <
author selects whether this is performed using OCSP or				      <
CRLs[.](#ajq_1366){#ajq_1366}\							      <
\										      <
The [TSS](#abbr_TSS){.abbr} shall describe when revocation checking is		      <
performed[.](#ajq_1367){#ajq_1367} It is expected that revocation		      <
checking is performed when a certificate is used in an authentication		      <
step[.](#ajq_1368){#ajq_1368} It is not sufficient to verify the status		      <
of a X.509 certificate only when it is loaded onto the				      <
device[.](#ajq_1369){#ajq_1369}\						      <
\										      <
This [SFR](#abbr_SFR){.abbr} lists the rules for validating			      <
certificates[.](#ajq_1370){#ajq_1370} The [ST](#abbr_ST){.abbr} author		      <
shall select whether revocation status is verified using OCSP or		      <
CRLs[.](#ajq_1371){#ajq_1371}							      <
[FIA\_X509\_EXT.2](#FIA_X509_EXT.2){.linkref} requires that certificates	      <
are used for trusted channels; this use requires that the			      <
extendedKeyUsage rules are verified[.](#ajq_1372){#ajq_1372}			      <
Certificates may optionally be used for code signing and policy signing		      <
and, if implemented, must be validated to contain the corresponding		      <
extendedKeyUsage[.](#ajq_1373){#ajq_1373}\					      <
\										      <
Regardless of the selection of implement functionality or invoke		      <
platform-provided functionality, the validation is expected to end in a		      <
trusted root CA certificate in a root store managed by the			      <
platform[.](#ajq_1374){#ajq_1374} ]{.note}					      <

    certificates\--conditional on whether CRL or OCSP is selected; if		      <
    both are selected, then a test shall be performed for each			      <
    method[.](#ajq_1384){#ajq_1384} The evaluator shall test revocation		      <
    of the node certificate and revocation of the intermediate CA		      <
    certificate (i.e[.](#ajq_1385){#ajq_1385} the intermediate CA		      <
    certificate should be revoked by the root					      <
    CA)[.](#ajq_1386){#ajq_1386} The evaluator shall ensure that a valid	      <
    certificate is used, and that the validation function			      <
    succeeds[.](#ajq_1387){#ajq_1387} The evaluator then attempts the		      <
    test with a certificate that has been revoked (for each method		      <
    chosen in the selection) to ensure when the certificate is no longer	      <
    valid that the validation function fails[.](#ajq_1388){#ajq_1388}		      <
-   **Test 4:** If OCSP is selected, the evaluator shall configure the		      <
    OCSP server or use a man-in-the-middle tool to present a certificate	      <
    that does not have the OCSP signing purpose and verify that			      <
    validation of the OCSP response fails[.](#ajq_1389){#ajq_1389} If		      <
    CRL is selected and the CA contains a Key Usage extension, the		      <
    evaluator shall configure the CA to sign a CRL with a certificate		      <
    that does not have the cRLsign key usage bit set, and verify that		      <
    validation of the CRL fails[.](#ajq_1390){#ajq_1390} If the CA is a		      <
    root CA with no Key Usage extension, this test is not			      <
    performed[.](#ajq_1391){#ajq_1391}						      <
-   **Test 5:** The evaluator shall modify any byte in the first eight		      <
    bytes of the certificate and demonstrate that the certificate fails		      <
    to validate[.](#ajq_1392){#ajq_1392} (The certificate will fail to		      <
    parse correctly.)								      <
-   **Test 6:** The evaluator shall modify any byte in the last byte of		      <
    the certificate and demonstrate that the certificate fails to		      <
    validate[.](#ajq_1393){#ajq_1393} (The signature on the certificate		      <
    will not validate.)								      <
-   **Test 7:** The evaluator shall modify any byte in the public key of	      <
    the certificate and demonstrate that the certificate fails to		      <
    validate[.](#ajq_1394){#ajq_1394} (The signature on the certificate		      <
    will not validate.)								      <

										      >	    the new trust anchor since the signature did not verify.

										      >	    ensure that it conforms with the format specified by RFC 2986. The

										      >	    user-input information.

::: {.element}									      |	Appendix B - Selection-Based Requirements {#sel-based-reqs .indexable data-level="A"}
::: {#FTP_ITC.1.1(2) .reqid}							      |	=========================================
[FTP\_ITC.1.1(2)](#FTP_ITC.1.1(2)){.abbr}					      <
:::										      <

::: {.reqdesc}									      |	As indicated in the introduction to this [PP](#abbr_PP), the baseline
The [TSF](#abbr_TSF){.abbr} shall \[**selection**: *invoke			      |	requirements (those that must be performed by the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) or
platform-provided functionality*, *implement functionality*\] to use		      |	its underlying platform) are contained in the body of this
\[**selection**: *TLS*, *DTLS*, *HTTPS*\] to provide a trusted			      |	[PP](#abbr_PP). There are additional requirements based on selections in
communication channel between itself and another trusted IT product that	      |	the body of the [PP](#abbr_PP): if certain selections are made, then
is logically distinct from other communication channels, provides		      |	additional requirements below must be included.
assured identification of its end points, protects channel data from		      <
disclosure, and detects modification of the channel				      <
data[.](#ajq_1456){#ajq_1456}							      <

::: {.appnote}									      |	B.1 Auditable Events for Selection-Based Requirements {#sel-based-reqs-audit .indexab
[Application Note: ]{.note-header}[ The intent of the mandatory portion		      |	-----------------------------------------------------
of the above requirement is to use the cryptographic protocols			      <
identified in the requirement to establish and maintain a trusted		      <
channel between the [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} and the				      <
[MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Agent[.](#ajq_1457){#ajq_1457} Only TLS, DTLS,		      <
or HTTPS are used in this trusted channel[.](#ajq_1458){#ajq_1458}\		      <
\										      <
This requirement is to ensure that the transmission of any audit logs,		      <
mobile device information data (software version, hardware model, and		      <
application versions), and configuration data collected by the			      <
[MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Agent and sent from the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr}		      <
Agent to the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Server, when commanded, or at		      <
configurable intervals, is properly protected[.](#ajq_1459){#ajq_1459}		      <
This trusted channel also protects any commands and policies sent by the	      <
[MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Server to the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr}			      <
Agent[.](#ajq_1460){#ajq_1460} Either the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Agent		      <
or the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Server is able to initiate the			      <
connection[.](#ajq_1461){#ajq_1461}\						      <
\										      <
For TLS connections between the MDM Server and Agent, the MDM Server is		      <
the Server side of the TLS connection, therefore it is appropriate to		      <
include the selection-based FCS\_TLSS SFRs in the ST, not FCS\_TLSC		      <
SFRs[.](#ajq_1462){#ajq_1462} With respect to mutual authentication, in		      <
cases where the Agent is outside of the [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr}, it		      <
should be verified that the server can support mutual authentication,		      <
meaning that the server includes support for client-side certificates		      <
for TLS mutual authentication post-enrollment[.](#ajq_1463){#ajq_1463}		      <
However, the client side is not evaluated since the agent is not in the		      <
[TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr}[.](#ajq_1464){#ajq_1464}\				      <
\										      <
This trusted channel protects both the connection between an enrolled		      <
[MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Agent and the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Server and	      <
the connection between an unenrolled [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Agent and		      <
the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Server during the enrollment			      <
operation[.](#ajq_1465){#ajq_1465} Different protocols can be used for		      <
these two connections, and the description in the				      <
[TSS](#abbr_TSS){.abbr} should make this difference				      <
clear[.](#ajq_1466){#ajq_1466}\							      <
\										      <
The trusted channel uses TLS, DTLS, or HTTPS as the protocol that		      <
preserves the confidentiality and integrity of [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr}		      <
communications[.](#ajq_1467){#ajq_1467} The [ST](#abbr_ST){.abbr} author	      <
chooses the mechanism or mechanisms supported by the				      <

Appendix C - Objective Requirements {#objective .indexable data-level="A"}	      |	::: {#FAU_STG_EXT.2 .comp}
===================================						      |	#### FAU\_STG\_EXT.2 Audit Event Storage
										      <
This appendix includes requirements that specify security functionality		      <
which also addresses threats[.](#ajq_1485){#ajq_1485} The requirements		      <
are not currently mandated in the body of this PP as they describe		      <
security functionality not yet widely-available in commercial			      <
technology[.](#ajq_1486){#ajq_1486} However, these requirements may be		      <
included in the ST such that the TOE is still conformant to this PP, and	      <
it is expected that they be included as soon as					      <
possible[.](#ajq_1487){#ajq_1487} As indicated in the introduction to		      <
this [PP](#abbr_PP){.abbr}, the baseline requirements (those that must		      <
be performed by the [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} or its underlying platform)		      <
are contained in the body of this						      <
[PP](#abbr_PP){.abbr}[.](#ajq_1488){#ajq_1488} There are additional		      <
requirements that specify security functionality that is desirable and		      <
these requirements are contained in this					      <
Appendix[.](#ajq_1489){#ajq_1489} It is expected that these requirements	      <
will transition from objective requirements to baseline requirements in		      <
future versions of this [PP](#abbr_PP){.abbr}[.](#ajq_1490){#ajq_1490}\		      <
\										      <
At any time these may be included in the [ST](#abbr_ST){.abbr} such that	      <
the [TOE](#abbr_TOE){.abbr} is still conformant to this				      <
[PP](#abbr_PP){.abbr}[.](#ajq_1491){#ajq_1491}\					      <
\										      <
This Appendix is divided into two subsections: objective requirements		      <
that may be performed by the [TSF](#abbr_TSF){.abbr} and objective		      <
requirements that may be performed by the [MDM](#abbr_MDM){.abbr} Agent		      <
or its underlying platform[.](#ajq_1492){#ajq_1492}\				      <
\										      <

										      >	The purpose of this requirement is to ensure that audit records are
										      >	stored securely. The [ST](#abbr_ST) author is responsible for selecting
										      >	whether audit records are maintained when audit storage or failure
										      >	occurs. The [ST](#abbr_ST) author must choose a means by which audit
										      >	records are saved and select the events during which the records will be
										      >	saved. The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) may rely on the underlying operating system
										      >	for this functionality, and the first selection should be made
										      >	appropriately.]{.note}

::: {#FIA_UAU_EXT.4(2) .comp}							      |	::: {.reqdesc}
#### FIA\_UAU\_EXT.4(2) User Authentication (Re-Use Prevention for Device Enrollment) |	The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) shall \[**selection**: *invoke platform-provided
										      >	functionality* , *implement functionality* \] to validate certificates
										      >	in accordance with the following rules:
										      >
										      >	-   RFC 5280 certificate validation and certificate path validation.
										      >	-   The certificate path must terminate with a trusted CA certificate.
										      >	-   The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) shall validate a certificate path by ensuring
										      >	    the presence of the basicConstraints extension, that the CA flag is
										      >	    set to TRUE for all CA certificates, and that any path constraints
										      >	    are met.
										      >	-   The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) shall validate that any CA certificate includes
										      >	    caSigning purpose in the key usage field.
										      >	-   The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) shall validate the revocation status of the
										      >	    certificate using \[**selection**: *OCSP as specified in RFC 6960* ,
										      >	    *CRL as specified in RFC 5280 Section 6.3* , *a CRL as specified in
										      >	    RFC 5759 Section 5* , *an OCSP TLS Status Request Extension (i.e.,
										      >	    OCSP stapling) as specified in RFC 6066* , *OCSP TLS
										      >	    Multi-Certificate Status Request Extension (i.e., OCSP
										      >	    Multi-Stapling) as specified in RFC 6961* , *no revocation method*
										      >	    \].
										      >	-   The [TSF](#abbr_TSF) shall validate the extendedKeyUsage field
										      >	    according to the following rules:\
										      >	    \
										      >	    -   Certificates used for trusted updates and executable code
										      >	        integrity verification shall have the Code Signing purpose
										      >	        (id-kp 3 with OID 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.3) in the extendedKeyUsage
										      >	        field.
										      >	    -   Server certificates presented for TLS shall have the Server
										      >	        Authentication purpose (id-kp 1 with OID 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.1) in
										      >	        the extendedKeyUsage field.
										      >	    -   Client certificates presented for TLS shall have the Client
										      >	        Authentication purpose (id-kp 2 with OID 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.2) in
										      >	        the EKU field.
										      >	    -   OCSP certificates presented for OCSP responses shall have the
										      >	        OCSP Signing purpose (id-kp 9 with OID 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.9) in the
										      >	        EKU field.
										      >	    -   Server certificates presented for [EST](#abbr_EST) shall have
										      >	        the CMC Registration Authority (RA) purpose (id-kp-cmcRA with
										      >	        OID 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.28) in the EKU field.
										      >
										      >	::: {.appnote}
										      >	[Application Note: ]{.note-header}[
										      >	[FIA\_X509\_EXT.1.1/CERTVAL\_SEL](#FIA_X509_EXT.1.1/CERTVAL_SEL) should
										      >	be chosen if the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) is distributed and the protocol(s)
										      >	selected in [FPT\_ITT.1/INTER\_XFER](#FPT_ITT.1/INTER_XFER) utilize
										      >	X.509 certificates for peer authentication. In this case, the use of
										      >	revocation list checking is optional as there are additional
										      >	requirements surrounding the enabling and disabling of the ITT channel
										      >	as defined in [FCO\_CPC\_EXT.1](#FCO_CPC_EXT.1). If revocation checking
										      >	is not supported, the [ST](#abbr_ST) author should select \'no
										      >	revocation method.\' However, if certificate revocation checking is
										      >	supported, the [ST](#abbr_ST) author selects whether this is performed
										      >	using OCSP or CRLs.\
										      >	\
										      >	This [SFR](#abbr_SFR) lists the rules for validating certificates. The
										      >	[ST](#abbr_ST) author shall select whether revocation status is verified
										      >	using OCSP or CRLs. [FIA\_X509\_EXT.2](#FIA_X509_EXT.2) requires that
										      >	certificates are used for trusted channels; this use requires that the
										      >	extendedKeyUsage rules are verified. Certificates may optionally be used
										      >	for code signing and policy signing and, if implemented, must be
										      >	validated to contain the corresponding extendedKeyUsage.\
										      >	\
										      >	OCSP stapling and OCSP multi-stapling only support TLS server
										      >	certificate validation. If other certificate types are validated, either
										      >	OCSP or CRL should be claimed. If OCSP is not supported the EKU
										      >	provision for checking the OCSP Signing purpose is met by default.\
										      >	\
										      >	Regardless of the selection of *implement functionality* or *invoke
										      >	platform-provided functionality* , the validation is expected to end in
										      >	a trusted root CA certificate in a root store managed by the platform.
										      >	]{.note}

::: {#FIA_X509_EXT.3 .comp}							      |	The tests described must be performed in conjunction with the other
#### FIA\_X509\_EXT.3 X509 Enrollment						      |	certificate services evaluation activities, including each of the
										      >	functions in [FIA\_X509\_EXT.2.1](#FIA_X509_EXT.2.1). The tests for the
										      >	extendedKeyUsage rules are performed in conjunction with the uses that
										      >	require those rules. The evaluator shall create a chain of at least
										      >	three certificates: the node certificate to be tested, an Intermediate
										      >	CA, and the self-signed Root CA.
										      >
										      >	-   **Test 1:** The evaluator shall demonstrate that validating a
										      >	    certificate without a valid certification path results in the
										      >	    function failing, for each of the following reasons, in turn:
										      >	    -   by establishing a certificate path in which one of the issuing
										      >	        certificates is not a CA certificate,
										      >	    -   by omitting the basicConstraints field in one of the issuing
										      >	        certificates,
										      >	    -   by setting the basicConstraints field in an issuing certificate
										      >	        to have CA=False,
										      >	    -   by omitting the CA signing bit of the key usage field in an
										      >	        issuing certificate, and
										      >	    -   by setting the path length field of a valid CA field to a value
										      >	        strictly less than the certificate path.
										      >
										      >	    The evaluator shall then establish a valid certificate path
										      >	    consisting of valid CA certificates, and demonstrate that the
										      >	    function succeeds. The evaluator shall then remove trust in one of
										      >	    the CA certificates, and show that the function fails.
										      >	-   **Test 2:** The evaluator shall demonstrate that validating an
										      >	    expired certificate results in the function failing.
										      >	-   **Test 3:** The evaluator shall test that the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) can
										      >	    properly handle revoked certificates\--conditional on whether CRL,
										      >	    OCSP or OCSP stapling is selected; if multiple methods are selected,
										      >	    then a test shall be performed for each method. The evaluator shall
										      >	    test revocation of the node certificate and revocation of the
										      >	    intermediate CA certificate (i.e. the intermediate CA certificate
										      >	    should be revoked by the root CA). If OCSP stapling per RFC 6066 is
										      >	    the only supported revocation method, testing revocation of the
										      >	    intermediate CA certificate is omitted. The evaluator shall ensure
										      >	    that a valid certificate is used, and that the validation function
										      >	    succeeds. The evaluator then attempts the test with a certificate
										      >	    that has been revoked (for each method chosen in the selection) to
										      >	    ensure when the certificate is no longer valid that the validation
										      >	    function fails.
										      >	-   **Test 4:** If OCSP option is selected, the evaluator shall send the
										      >	    [TOE](#abbr_TOE) an OCSP response signed by a certificate that does
										      >	    not have the OCSP signing purpose and verify that validation of the
										      >	    OCSP response fails. If CRL is selected, the evaluator shall cause a
										      >	    CA to sign a CRL with a certificate that has a key usage extension
										      >	    but does not have the cRLsign key usage bit set, and verify that
										      >	    validation of the CRL fails.
										      >	-   **Test 5:** The evaluator shall modify any byte in the first eight
										      >	    bytes of the certificate and demonstrate that the certificate fails
										      >	    to validate. (The certificate will fail to parse correctly.)
										      >	-   **Test 6:** The evaluator shall modify any byte in the last byte of
										      >	    the certificate and demonstrate that the certificate fails to
										      >	    validate. (The signature on the certificate will not validate.)
										      >	-   **Test 7:** The evaluator shall modify any byte in the public key of
										      >	    the certificate and demonstrate that the certificate fails to
										      >	    validate. (The signature on the certificate will not validate.)
										      >	-   **Test 8:**\
										      >	    Test 8a: (Conditional on support for EC certificates as indicated in
										      >	    [FCS\_COP.1/SIGN\_ALG](#FCS_COP.1/SIGN_ALG)). The evaluator shall
										      >	    establish a valid, trusted certificate chain consisting of an EC
										      >	    leaf certificate, an EC Intermediate CA certificate not designated
										      >	    as a trust anchor, and an EC certificate designated as a trusted
										      >	    anchor, where the elliptic curve parameters are specified as a named
										      >	    curve. The evaluator shall confirm that the [TOE](#abbr_TOE)
										      >	    validates the certificate chain.\
										      >	    \
										      >	    Test 8b: (Conditional on support for EC certificates as indicated in
										      >	    [FCS\_COP.1/SIGN\_ALG](#FCS_COP.1/SIGN_ALG)). The evaluator shall
										      >	    replace the intermediate certificate in the certificate chain for
										      >	    Test 8a with a modified certificate, where the modified intermediate
										      >	    CA has a public key information field where the EC parameters uses
										      >	    an explicit format version of the Elliptic Curve parameters in the
										      >	    public key information field of the intermediate CA certificate from
										      >	    Test 8a, and the modified Intermediate CA certificate is signed by
										      >	    the trusted EC root CA, but having no other changes. The evaluator
										      >	    shall confirm the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) treats the certificate as
										      >	    invalid.

activity)[.](#ajq_1631){#ajq_1631}\						      |	[Application Note: ]{.note-header}[ The intent of the mandatory portion
										      >	of the above requirement is to use the cryptographic protocols
										      >	identified in the requirement to establish and maintain a trusted
										      >	channel between the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) and the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent. If
										      >	the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) includes a separate MAS Server, this requirement
										      >	also addresses the communication between the MAS Server and the
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent. Only TLS, DTLS, or HTTPS are used in this
										      >	trusted channel.\
										      >	\
										      >	This requirement is to ensure that the transmission of any audit logs,
										      >	mobile device information data (software version, hardware model, and
										      >	application versions), and configuration data collected by the
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent and sent from the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent to the
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server, when commanded, or at configurable intervals,
										      >	is properly protected. This trusted channel also protects any commands
										      >	and policies sent by the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server to the [MDM](#abbr_MDM)
										      >	Agent. Either the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent or the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server
										      >	is able to initiate the connection.\
										      >	\
										      >	For TLS connections between the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server and Agent, the
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server is the Server side of the TLS connection,
										      >	therefore it is appropriate to include the selection-based FCS\_TLSS
										      >	SFRs in the [ST](#abbr_ST), not FCS\_TLSC SFRs. With respect to mutual
										      >	authentication, in cases where the Agent is outside of the
										      >	[TOE](#abbr_TOE), it should be verified that the server can support
										      >	mutual authentication, meaning that the server includes support for
										      >	client-side certificates for TLS mutual authentication post-enrollment.
										      >	However, the client side is not evaluated since the agent is not in the
										      >	[TOE](#abbr_TOE).\
										      >	\
										      >	This trusted channel protects the connection between an enrolled
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent and the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server.
										      >	[FTP\_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH\_ENROLL](#FTP_TRP.1/TRUSTPATH_ENROLL) provides a
										      >	trusted channel to protect the connection between an unenrolled
										      >	[MDM](#abbr_MDM) Agent and the [MDM](#abbr_MDM) Server during the
										      >	enrollment operation.\
										      >	\
										      >	The trusted channel uses TLS, DTLS, or HTTPS as the protocol that
										      >	preserves the confidentiality and integrity of [MDM](#abbr_MDM)
										      >	communications. The [ST](#abbr_ST) author chooses the mechanism or
										      >	mechanisms supported by the [TOE](#abbr_TOE).\
										      >	\
										      >	If the [ST](#abbr_ST) author selects \"mutually authenticated TLS as
										      >	defined in the Package for Transport Layer Security\" or \"mutually
										      >	authenticated DTLS as defined in the Package for Transport Layer
										      >	Security\", the [TSF](#abbr_TSF) must be validated against requirements
										      >	from the Package for Transport Layer Security, with the following
										      >	selections made: ]{.note}
										      >
										      >	-   FCS\_TLS\_EXT.1:
										      >	    -   either TLS or DTLS is selected depending on the selection made
										      >	        in
										      >	        [FTP\_ITC.1.1/INTER\_TSF\_XFER\_AGENT](#FTP_ITC.1.1/INTER_TSF_XFER_AGENT)
										      >	    -   server must be selected
										      >	-   FCS\_TLSS\_EXT.1.1:
										      >	    -   The cipher suites selected must correspond with the algorithms
										      >	        and hash functions allowed in FCS\_COP.1.
										      >	    -   mutual authentication must be selected
										      >
										      >	Protocol, RBG, Certificate validation, algorithm, and similar services
										      >	may be met with platform provided services.\
										      >	\
										      >	The requirement implies that not only are communications protected when
										      >	they are initially established, but also on resumption after an outage.
										      >	It may be the case that some part of the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) setup involves
										      >	manually setting up tunnels to protect other communication, and if after
										      >	an outage the [TOE](#abbr_TOE) attempts to re-establish the
										      >	communication automatically with (the necessary) manual intervention,
										      >	there may be a window created where an attacker might be able to gain
										      >	critical information or compromise a connection.\
